text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with crunchy spicy chickpea x'
that's right you know a recipe comes out
good when the biggest problem you have
is whether to call it crispy or crunchy
and such was the case with this
delicious easy to make oven fried snack
so I flipped an imaginary coin and
decided to go with crunchy but either
way these are incredibly addictive and
something I think everyone should know
how to make so let's go ahead and get
started and in the words of the great
Montell Jordan
this is how we do it so the first thing
we're going to need is some chickpeas
they're also known as garbanzo beans or
chichi beans although I believe that
one's a little bit naughty and while
this snack is most often made with
canned beans I really think the dried
are far superior which is what we're
going to use here and of course since we
are using the dried beans we're going to
have to soak them first so this recipe
is going to start out very similar to
the falafel recipe we just did in fact
it's so similar I'm just going to reuse
the same footage so what we need to do
is cover our dried beans with cold water
and let them soak for 24 hours at which
point they should look like this and
then what we'll need to do is drain
these very very well okay we don't to
put these in the oven wet so not only
will we drain those will also lay some
paper towels in our baking dish so that
we can blot off any excess moisture so
we'll roll those around a little bit on
the paper towel and that should dry them
off pretty good and once we've done that
we will remove the paper and proceed
with this very simple two-step process
which is basically cut with some olive
oil and spices and then bake in a hot
oven till crispy it really is that
simple so we'll start by drizzling in
some olive oil and now I'm not measuring
this we just need enough to generously
coat them of course on the blog post I
listed is two tablespoons which is what
I always put for the oil when I'm not
exactly sure and then once that set is
time to season these up and the sky's
the limit
okay we'll start with some salt that's
pretty much mandatory but after that you
put what you like
I will reluctantly tell you what I used
but I really do want you to make this
recipe your own so after the salt I
added some freshly ground black pepper
as well as some ground cumin that's one
of my favorite all-purpose spices and
works really well here I also decide to
put in a little bit of chili powder I
used a little bit of smoked paprika but
really any kind of ground chili is going
to work beautifully and speaking of
ground chilies we'll also add a nice
shake of cayenne and once our chickpeas
are oiled and seasoned we will
that a good mix until those are all
nicely and evenly coated and as I've
already mentioned canned chickpeas are
much more common for this recipe but I
just don't think those come out as
crunchy plus they are significantly more
expensive than the dried version but
anyway we'll give those a mix and then
we should probably give them the old
shakey shake ax we really do want these
in just a single layer at which point
they're ready for the oven
so let's transfer those into the center
of a preheated a 400 degree oven for
about an hour or until crunchy and what
we're going to want to do at least two
or three times while these are cooking
is pull them out and give them a good
mix and by the way when I say this is
going to take about an hour then of
course is going to vary could be 45
minutes could be an hour and five
minutes for example these because I'm
using a baking dish with high sides it's
going to take a little longer than
someone using a regular sheet pan but
the reason I do use a dish like this is
because these things love to escape the
pan as you're stirring them so fair
warning if you use like a cookie sheet
or something you'll have these things
rolling all over your kitchen and I'm
only going to show it once but like I
said you want to do that a couple more
times during the cooking process so I'll
pop those back in and continue baking
tossing occasionally until they look
like this they should brown it
beautifully and be very crunchy / crispy
and by the way I know it looks like
there's a lot of spice to left in the
oil but don't worry as you'll see these
chickpeas have absorbed all that flavor
and then speaking of the oil we do want
to let these cool down a little bit but
not sitting in the oil so I do like to
transfer these onto a rack at this point
that's going to allow any excess oil to
drip off and I think the final result is
going to be a little bit crunch here and
I know you would have totally taken my
word for that these are super crunchy
but just in case we have a few skeptics
let's listen in so that is the sound
you're looking for and the sound you
shall have as long as you cook these
long enough
and by the way the longer you cook these
the crunchy er they get unless you go
too far and then they burn and then you
have nothing so like so many things in
life you'll have to figure out that
whole risk reward thing so don't stop
till they're crunchy but don't push it
too far past that
otherwise you'll be starting over and
have to wait an entire day to give
another try but anyway that's it crunchy
spicy chickpeas these were undoubtedly
one of the world's first crunchy snack
foods I mean I've done no research on
that but I bet you anything they were
and by the way if you kind of squint
these do look like hundreds of tiny
little basketballs
which would make this the perfect snack
for your March Madness viewing party all
right so I really do hope you give these
a try head over to food wishes comm for
all the ingredient amounts and more info
as usual and as always enjoy
